description: Probably a variation of slug (“to hit very hard”) or slough.
Possibly related to slag, seen in the North Germanic languages, in association with the third verb and second noun definition.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, chiefly Britain, Australia and Canada) A long, tedious walk, or session of work.
(countable, cricket) An aggressive shot played with little skill.

verbs.description: slog (third-person singular simple present slogs, present participle slogging, simple past and past participle slogged)

examples: A miraculous desert rain. We slog, dripping, into As Safi, Jordan. We drive the sodden mules through wet streets. To the town’s only landmark. To the “Museum at the Lowest Place on Earth.”

entries.meaning: (by extension) To work slowly and deliberately at a tedious task.
To strike something with a heavy blow, especially a ball with a bat.
